title: Scott Heady on Marian: 'We're going to build a championship program'
text:
Scott Heady on Marian: 'We're going to build a championship program' Jordan J Wilson , jordan.wilson@indystar.com Published 5:19 p.m. ET Feb. 20, 2017 | Updated 10 hours ago CLOSE x Share Newly named Marian University men's basketball head coach Scott Heady state his two goals for the team during his official announcement as the Knights' new coach on Monday, Feb. 20, 2017. INDIANAPOLIS – Scott Heady knows basketball. The game surrounded him growing up as the son of an Indiana high school Hall of Famer, and it has remained a fixture in his life as a high school coach for the past 22 seasons. 
Heady also knows success. In his seventh season with Carmel, he has posted a 137-37 record and won two Class 4A state championships and four sectional titles. 
A quick look around the foyer of Marian’s Physical Education Center proves the Knights know success, too. Two display cases are filled with trophies and plaques awarded in football, volleyball, golf – even bowling. One of the largest and most recent is the basketball netting from the women’s basketball team’s 2016 national championship. 
Not one visible award reads "men’s basketball," though the Knights have been to the NAIA tournament four times, reaching the Elite Eight in 2001. 
After being named Marian’s new men’s basketball coach last Thursday , though, Heady does not expect the lack of success to last much longer. 
"We're going to build a championship program,” Heady said Monday at his introductory news conference in a room filled with his future colleagues in the Marian athletic department. “We want to start right now building a championship culture. That's where it starts." Facebook A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Marian athletic director Steve Downing has an inherent affection for basketball, being a three-year letter winner at Indiana under Bob Knight, in addition to being a member of the 1974 NBA champion Boston Celtics. All the more reason Downing, too, wants the men’s basketball to grow into a national contender. 
Downing originally considered Heady for the position when it was last available in 2015 after former Butler coach Todd Lickliter resigned with a 49-36 record after three seasons. Heady got to know the Marian program through the process and came away understanding the Knights better despite Downing going in another direction. 
Two years later, Heady’s familiarity helped make Downing’s decision easy. Even easier considering what Downing already knew and admired about Heady. 
“I’ve had my most success with people that haven’t coached at all or were high school coaches,” Downing said. “I just think they tend to be a lot more hungrier because they do have a desire maybe to get to where some of these (other college) guys are. That’s what I wanted to do with basketball was to get a guy who was hungry.” 
Downing also conceded the obvious about bringing in a highly-respected local coach: recruiting. He expects Heady’s connections to area high school and AAU coaches and players will enhance his ability to build a “winning program” at Marian, and Heady doesn’t disagree. Buy Photo 
Dave Green, left, tells Scott Heady's son, Luke, 16, that he's known him since he was just "a little guy," before Heady is official announced as the head coach of the Marian University Knights' men's basketball team on Monday, Feb. 20, 2017. Green met Scott Heady at Warren Central where they were both involved in athletics. (Photo: Mykal McEldowney/IndyStar) 
Certainly, Heady will need to learn the nuances of recruiting at the college level as well as the limitations of scholarship funds at an NAIA school, but few college coaches out there can claim to know Indiana basketball as well as Heady. 
“I think the best high school coaches in the country are right here in Indiana,” Heady said. “Having that base of contacts and relationships is going to be a benefit right away, and then the (Metropolitan Interscholastic Conference) conference and competing in that MIC conference and the schedule that we play at Carmel every year. Night in and night out in the MIC, you’ve got four or five Division I players at one time on the floor, so it’s not like I’m coming in and I’m not used to coaching against some talented players.” 
Heady anticipates the transition to be a challenge. Right now, he is essentially balancing two jobs – both guiding the No. 10 Greyhounds (17-4) into the state tournament and getting started on building the future of Marian basketball. 
After speaking with the media, Heady will take his first step into the latter territory and meet with his future players for the first time. He won’t talk about the past during their meeting. Instead, he hopes to impart a few words about what he expects. 
“It’s all about today and moving forward,” Heady said. “That’s all we’re focusing on.”
